The Cabinet had before them a Memorandum bythe Tome Secretary and the Secretary of State forthe Colonies in regard to the new reference to theJudicial Committee of the Privy Council, in which theashed that the Governments legal representativesbefore the Judicial Committee should urge that decisions by a majority should be valid, and, further that in the despatch informing the Irish Free Statethat this question is being laid before the JudicialCommittee, it should be stated that, while It wouldbe premature to anticipate what the finding of theCommittee on this point will be, it would, in theopinion of His Majesty's Government, be incompatible with the honourable observance of uhe intentions ofthe Treaty to allow the proceedings of the Commissionto be brought to nullity by x-eason of such a finding(Paper O.P.-403 (24')). After hearing the Attorney-General and the lord advocate, who pointed out the legal difficulties in theway of interpreting Article 12 of the Treaty as enabling amajority to prevail, the Cabinet agreed (a) That while Counsel for the Governmentin opening the case before the Committeeof the Privy Council should adopt ingeneral a non-contentious attitude, theyshould be instructed to state, withspecial reference to the additionalquestion now to be added, that in the -viewof the Government the Treaty as confirmed by Parliament was intended to be an effective instrument and that the Governmentwould view with great regret advice tendered to His Majesty which would in any way tendto prevent the Treaty from achievinp; thepurpose for which it was designed.(b) That, in the despatch informing the IrishFree State that this question is being laid before the Judicial Committee of"the privy Council, the Secretary of State forthe Colonies should be authorised to makeit clear that the question had been put atthe request of the Gbaimiian-Designate, butthat His Majesty's Government take theview that the intention of the Treaty wasthat decisions by a majority should bevalid, and that the Government's legalrepresentatives would be instructed "to impress upon the Judicial Committee the considerations in favour of this view andthe importance of its prevailing. TheSecretary of State should, however, avoid any suggestion at this st-'*ge that theBritish"Government contemplated legislation in the event of an adverse decision by theJudicial Committee of the Privy Council.The form of the communication to the IrishFree State, whether by official despatch orconfidential letter to the President ofthe Executive Council, was left to theSecretary of State.
